bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, September 3, 1941

div1.p: Kean informs Hench that Reed read his paper on the etiology of yellow fever at the Pan American Medical Congress in Havana, Feb 4-7, 1901. While Wood was convinced of the need to destroy mosquitoes, Gorgas was not and only began mosquito eradication at Wood's command.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, September 3, 1941
div1.opener:
addendum
Note for Dr. Hench
Sept 3, 1941
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.
div1.p:
General Winter's article The Romantic
Conquest of Yellow Fever was publish-
ed in the Military Surgeon while
I was the Editor of that monthly
medical journal- This was a car-
bon file copy of a note which I
appended to his article as to the
date at which the mosquito work
in Havana was begun- The date
Feb. 4. 1901 given by Gen. Winter was
taken by him from Gorgas, Report. You will
probably recognize at the date of meeting
of the Pan American Medical Congress at
Havana Cuba Feb. 4-7 1901 before which
Walter Reed read his paper “The Etiology of
Yellow Fever- An additional Note” (over)

appended herewith was a carbon of Kean's editorial,
appendex to Winters article - see my copy of Winters article

at the end of which are the eleven
famous conclusions which I heard
Dr. F. F. Russell say a couple of years
ago have not one of them been contro-
verted in all the years of work since
Feb. 4, 1901- Please note the name of
Dr. F. F. Russell on the letter head of
Dr. H. R. Carter's letter inclosed- I have
checked it with a blue pencil.

Of course no mosquito killing began
on that date as Gorgas was as he himself
admits entirely incredulous- But
his commanding officer Gen. Wood
was convinced and started Gorgas to
work- The organization of the work
was however a matter of some complexity
and as G. O. No. 6. Hdqrs Div. of Cuba applied
only to Military garrisons and not to the City
I am certain that the Kerosine Brigades did not get to
work before March
